sites.title: Statue of Liberty
sites.summary: Iconic symbol of freedom gifted by France, featuring a torch and tablet.
sites.description_md:
# Statue of Liberty

Dedicated on October 28, 1886, this colossal statue of Libertas was a gift from France. It depicts a robed female figure holding a torch and tablet, symbolising freedom and democracy. Visitors can tour the island and ascend to the crown for panoramic views.

citations.label: NYC Tourism – Statue of Liberty history

sites.title: Central Park
sites.summary: Vast urban park between the Upper West and Upper East sides, offering recreation and nature.
sites.description_md:
# Central Park

This 843‑acre park, proposed in the 1840s and opened in 1857, is the most visited urban park in the United States. It features rolling meadows, woodland paths, lakes, and landmarks like Bethesda Terrace and the Ramble.

sites.title: Empire State Building
sites.summary: Art Deco skyscraper offering observatories with sweeping views of Manhattan.
sites.description_md:
# Empire State Building

Completed in 1931, the 102‑story Empire State Building was the world's tallest building for nearly 40 years. Its observation decks on the 86th and 102nd floors provide iconic views of New York City.

sites.title: Metropolitan Museum of Art
sites.summary: One of the world's largest art museums, housing over two million works.
sites.description_md:
# Metropolitan Museum of Art

Founded in 1870, the Met spans 17 curatorial departments and displays art from antiquity to the present. Highlights include Egyptian temples, European paintings and American decorative arts.

sites.title: Brooklyn Bridge
sites.summary: Suspension bridge connecting Manhattan and Brooklyn, known for its Gothic towers.
sites.description_md:
# Brooklyn Bridge

Opened in 1883, the Brooklyn Bridge was the first steel‑wire suspension bridge. It spans the East River, linking Manhattan and Brooklyn, and offers pedestrian and cycling paths with scenic views of the skyline.

sites.title: High Line
sites.summary: Elevated linear park built on a historic freight rail line on Manhattan’s West Side.
sites.description_md:
# High Line

The High Line repurposes an elevated freight rail line into a 1.45‑mile park featuring gardens, art installations, and views of the Hudson River. Opened in 2009, it revitalized the Chelsea neighbourhood.

citations.label: Friends of the High Line – History

sites.title: 9/11 Memorial & Museum
sites.summary: Memorial and museum commemorating the victims of the September 11, 2001 attacks.
sites.description_md:
# 9/11 Memorial & Museum

Located at the World Trade Center, the memorial features twin reflecting pools set within the footprints of the Twin Towers. The adjacent museum documents the events of 9/11 and honours those who lost their lives.

sites.title: Broadway Theatre District
sites.summary: Cluster of historic theatres along Broadway known for world‑class productions.
sites.description_md:
# Broadway Theatre District

Broadway encompasses the 41 professional theatres with 500 or more seats located in Manhattan's Theatre District. It is synonymous with live theatre and has launched countless acclaimed productions.

sites.title: American Museum of Natural History
sites.address: 200 Central Park West, New York, NY 10024
sites.summary: One of the world’s preeminent scientific institutions exploring earth, space and life sciences.
sites.description_md:
# American Museum of Natural History

Founded in 1869, the museum houses over 34 million specimens. Exhibits range from fossils and gems to cosmic displays in the Hayden Planetarium.

citations.label: American Museum of Natural History – About

sites.title: Times Square
sites.summary: Bustling commercial intersection famed for neon signs and New Year's Eve celebrations.
sites.description_md:
# Times Square

Known as ‘The Crossroads of the World,’ Times Square is where Broadway and Seventh Avenue intersect. It is lined with theatres, shops, and electronic billboards and hosts New York’s New Year’s Eve ball drop.
